newsitem.title: FRANCE: SOCCER-PSG SEEK REHABILITATION AT THIRD DIVISION GROUND.
newsitem.headline: SOCCER-PSG SEEK REHABILITATION AT THIRD DIVISION GROUND.

text.p: Crisis club Paris Saint-Germain will not be dwelling on the romantic aspect of the French Cup that pits holders Auxerre against the amateurs of a tiny village in northern France in the first round this weekend.

A trip to third division Besancon on Sunday which PSG might have regarded as a leisurely country stroll is now, their confidence in tatters after their European Super Cup humiliation by Juventus, a hard-nosed search for rehabilitation.
"The revolution has to happen on the pitch, from Sunday against Besancon in the French Cup and in the (first division) championship at Monaco (a week later)," PSG chief executive Michel Denisot said.

Underdogs Besancon will try to take advantage of the doubts afflicting PSG's players, but could find themselves the victims of a backlash from a side who above all else will be looking to restore their pride.

"We're having a hard time coming out of the nightmare of Wednesday against Juventus," Denisot said. "But we're going there concentrated. It will be difficult and we're going to prepare for this match very seriously."
Veteran defender Paul Le Guen said: "We'll be a little bit afraid at Besancon."
Panama striker Julio Cesar Dely Valdes has been dropped from Wednesday's side in favour of the newly-signed Cyrille Pouget.

Auxerre face a minor league team whose 64-year-old coach Serge Durand does a paper round on his bicycle in Vervins, a village of 3,000, and whose striker admires the French league and Cup double winners' goalkeeper Lionel Charbonnier.

"For me, at the end of my days on the bench, I could not have dreamt of a more beautiful story," Durand said as he contemplated playing against European Cup contenders Auxerre in front of 10,000 people at the nearby town of Saint-Quentin.
The match was switched from the village close to the Belgian border where Vervins, whose pitch is frozen, normally play in front of 150 spectators.
"We have no tactic, other than to delay as long as possible the moment when we concede the first (goal)," Durand said.
